data.message:
Well I converted from VueJS to React for my current project and the whole process was very smooth. I don't understand why all the fuss. I was a little bit prejudiced about JSX but it didn't even touch me (JSX with emmet is just like HTML with emmet). Also writing in JSX it feels more javascript. I learned React from a known video tutor in a day, and the whole basic port took about 2 days. Now its time to discover redux too and compare it to Vuex.

Yeah I know, I learned from the opposite order Vue->React. But I think the reason that I grasped so easily React, was that I had already understood the whole concept.

Dope! 16.2 added the Fragment syntax (and <> sugar). 
Using arrays for parentless components wasn't really good an experience.

Hey, I've just published new article about well-crafted components. Recently, I've seen quite a lot of code, that's more focused on immediate results than long-term maintainability and I wanted to share my thoughts. I'm discussing single responsibility principle & separation of concerns with some examples. Please take a look & let me know what do you think üòÉ
data.caption: reallifeprogramming.com
data.story: Bartek Witczak shared a link to the group: ReactJS.
data.description: We value code that is easy to maintain over code that is easy to write
data.name: Why well-crafted components matter? ‚Äì Real Life Programming

data.message: Hey all! Any recommendations for React components that display the output of a command line process? My goal was to find a simple component that could run a predefined terminal command (one that runs continuously) and display the output, but I didn't find anything that would be a fairly seamless drop. I looked at react-bash and one or two other components, but it didn't seem like they offered examples that would let you run/spawn a true command line process. Any ideas? If not no biggie; I'll just run it separately for now and wait until I get my Redux stuff integrated :)

Here are the React-specific sessions at Assert(js):

1. Aaron Abramov (Jest core team / Facebook): "Establishing testing patterns with software design principles"

2. Mary Snow (Codesmith): Testing React Applications

3. Rotem Mizrachi-Meidan (Detox project core team / Wix): Testing React Native apps with Detox

And a full-day hands-on training session by Kent C. Dodds (PayPal & TC39) on testing React apps.

(And lots of other more general JS talks.)

Early-bird tickets are still available (but only for 2 more days).

data.message:
Many members in the group ask about how to start learning React or how to move beyond the basics, so I‚Äôve put together a comprehensive guide that captures what online courses are available to learn React and other web development skills when you're broke, short on time, on a budget, or looking to advance your expertise and skill set.

My goal with this post is to inspire folks along their developer journey and provide them with resources that can help them overcome the obstacles that may get in the way of their learning.

If you're up for it, join me for the Earn & Learn Coding Challenge.

https://www.inventwithcode.com/best-courses-for-web-developers/ 

Also, if I missed any resources, feel free to post them in the comments. I'm always looking for new resources to recommend!

Hi everyone,

I'm thinking of implementing react-ga (Google analytics) to my web app, there are a lot of things I want to track such as; Page view, Crash report, Specific event interactions, etc. 

The implementations should be straight-forward, but, how do I track user detail (Unique user) from Web perspective ? 

Which will lead us to more specific cases (What if they clear their cookies, what if they logged in from incognito mode or different browser), in those cases, how do I know if they're the same user or not ?

There are a lot of questions I wanted to ask (regarding web analytics), but let's start from the basic analytics first.

Thanks

data.message:
Does anyone know of a native text/code editor except notepad++ and sublime text?

Update: I see someone confuses native with atom and vscode, to clarify by native i mean native to the os itself atom/vscode are not native they are based on electron which is like the cordova/phonegap wrapper and they depend on html/css/js, and the reason i ask this is because this type of editors are very slow especially atom, even on decent cpu and ram, they just can't handle large files and typing becomes laggy, also the startup its really bad, thats why i ask if there is some native editor built on c#/c++ for windows it can be just editor with syntax support or IDE doesn't matter.. thnx. :)
